original_data.question: An otherwise healthy 15-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with extreme fatigue and shortness of breath. His temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), the blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg and the pulse is 100/min. Past medical history is noncontributory and he takes no medication. His father and aunt both suffer from mild anemia. On examination, he is very pale and his spleen is enlarged. His hemoglobin is 5 g/dL and platelet count is slightly reduced. His peripheral blood smear is shown in the picture. Over the next 2 weeks, the patient recovers, and his hemoglobin is 11 g/dL. Which of the following best represents the pattern of inheritance of this patient underlying disorder?

model_response:
The peripheral blood smear shows numerous target cells and a few nucleated red blood cells. The patient has the characteristic presentation of a hemolytic anemia due to a membrane abnormality. The most likely diagnosis is hereditary spherocytosis. The pattern of inheritance of hereditary spherocytosis is autosomal dominant.

Hereditary spherocytosis is caused by diverse mutations that lead to an insufficiency of membrane skeletal components. The loss of membrane skeletal components leads to loss of membrane stability, and consequently spherical rather than biconcave shape of red cells. The loss of membrane causes the red cells to be less deformable, and thus more prone to splenic sequestration and destruction. The loss of membrane also causes the red cells to be less able to exchange ions with the surrounding plasma, and thus more prone to oxidative injury. The most common mutations involve the gene coding for ankyrin, but mutations involving other genes coding for membrane skeletal proteins are also common.

The diagnosis of hereditary spherocytosis is usually readily established by a positive family history, splenomegaly, and the characteristic peripheral blood smear. The diagnosis is confirmed by osmotic fragility testing and flow cytometry. The treatment of hereditary spherocytosis is splenectomy, which is usually followed by a dramatic improvement in hemolysis and anemia.

Hereditary spherocytosis is a genetically heterogeneous disorder with autosomal dominant inheritance. Hereditary spherocytosis is caused by diverse mutations that lead to an insufficiency of membrane skeletal components. The loss of membrane skeletal components leads to loss of membrane stability, and consequently spherical rather than biconcave shape of red cells. The loss of membrane also causes the red cells to be less able to exchange ions with the surrounding plasma, and thus more prone to oxidative injury. The most common mutations involve the gene coding for ankyrin, but mutations involving other genes coding for membrane skeletal proteins are also common.

The treatment of hereditary spherocytosis is splenectomy, which is usually followed by a dramatic improvement in hemolysis and anemia.

###Answer: OPTION A IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Having no significant health-related issues.

The state of weariness following a period of exertion, mental or physical, characterized by a decreased capacity for work and reduced efficiency to respond to stimuli.

The air that is inhaled and exhaled during respiration.

A metric unit of length equal to one thousandth of a meter (10E-3 meter) or approximately 0.03937 inch.
The rhythmical expansion and contraction of an ARTERY produced by waves of pressure caused by the ejection of BLOOD from the left ventricle of the HEART as it contracts.
A record of a patient's background regarding health and the occurrence of disease events of the individual. In addition, personal medical history may be a variable in epidemiologic studies.

A reduction in the number of circulating ERYTHROCYTES or in the quantity of HEMOGLOBIN.

A clinical manifestation consisting of an unnatural paleness of the skin.
An encapsulated lymphatic organ through which venous blood filters.
An extract of Goa powder; a complex mixture of reduction products of chrysophanic acid, emodin, and emodin monomethyl ether; used locally in ringworm, psoriasis, and eczema.
The number of PLATELETS per unit volume in a sample of venous BLOOD.
Made less in size or amount or degree.

A liquid tissue; its major function is to transport oxygen throughout the body. It also supplies the tissues with nutrients, removes waste products, and contains various components of the immune system defending the body against infection. Several hormones also travel in the blood.
An image recorded by a camera.
Any period of seven consecutive days.

A definite pathologic process with a characteristic set of signs and symptoms. It may affect the whole body or any of its parts, and its etiology, pathology, and prognosis may be known or unknown.
